ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

YISHUN MEDICAL CENTRE
(Conversion into a polyclinic)


    1. Mr Ong Ah Heng asked the Minister for Health what are the plans for the conversion of Yishun Medical Centre into a polyclinic.

     The Senior Minister of State for Health (Dr Aline K. Wong) (for the Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, Sir, in 1992, the Review Committee on Health Policies recommended that the Government explore alternative approaches in providing primary health care, eg, to provide customised multi-purpose buildings to be leased to general practitioners and group practices. At that time, as the proposed Yishun Polyclinic was under construction, my Ministry decided to convert the polyclinic into a medical centre as a pilot project.

    The Ministry appointed EM Services Pte Ltd as its managing agent for Yishun Medical Centre. EM Services advertised in the press to lease out the units. Despite repeated attempts using various measures to market the units, the uptake was poor. As we did not want the building to be grossly under-utilised, we also allowed non-medical related agencies to rent the units in the Yishun Medical Centre.

    Towards the end of the 3-year pilot project, the Ministry conducted a review of this scheme. It concluded that it has not been successful and decided to explore the possibility of converting Yishun Medical Centre into a polyclinic when the leases of the tenants expire. The Land Office had also indicated that if the building was not being used for medical purposes, it should be returned to the Land Office.

    In February this year, we received Mr Ong Ah Heng's appeal to convert the Yishun Medical Centre into a Government polyclinic, arising from numerous requests from residents for a polyclinic in Yishun. Since most of the tenants' leases

Column: 234

were coming to an end in March and April 1997, my Ministry decided to convert the Yishun Medical Centre into a polyclinic.

    The polyclinic will occupy the first two floors. It will provide a one-stop centre for outpatient services and maternal and child health care. It will have a laboratory and an X-ray facility.

    We are now in the process of requesting for funds for the conversion and plan to start the renovation works in a few months' time. It will take about six months to convert the building into a polyclinic.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD FLATS
(Longer loan repayment periods for older applicants)


    2. Mr Leong Horn Kee asked the Minister for National Development whether the Housing and Development Board will be flexible in allowing longer loan repayment periods for older applicants who have been allocated new HDB flats, if they are able to secure repayment contributions from their children or relatives.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, older applicants can include additional family members such as their children as flat lessees or occupiers. In such cases, the age of the youngest joint purchaser will be used in the computation of the maximum loan repayment period. The combined incomes of all the purchasers will also be used to determine the maximum loan quantum.

    There are also other existing provisions for older applicants who have been allocated new HDB flats. In line with the Government's objective to help low-income applicants, HDB is exempting the low-income families from credit assessment. Therefore, older applicants who are buying 3-room or smaller flats direct from HDB as well as those who purchase flats under HDB's Low Income Family Incentives Scheme would be exempted from credit assessment.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Sir, can I get a clarification from the Minister? If an applicant is staying in a

Column: 235

3-room HDB rental flat and by the time he wants to purchase this rental flat he is already quite old, can he be allowed to get a longer loan repayment period for such a purchase?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, HDB, as the public housing authority, has a mission to help Singaporeans own their first flat. In the case that the Member raised of a family who is renting a flat for some time and later on is able to afford either a new flat or the flat that he is staying in, HDB will consider such cases favourably. Even if the head of the family is in the mid-40s, HDB will extend the period of the loan to allow him to buy over his rental flat or to buy a small HDB flat for the first time.

CHANGES IN PUBLIC HOUSING REGULATIONS
(Objectives)


    3. Mr Leong Horn Kee asked the Minister for National Development what are the objectives of the recent announcements of changes in public housing regulations and whether he intends to introduce further changes in public and private housing policies.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, in April 1997, the revised mortgage financing policy was announced to bring the mortgage financing policy for HDB flats closer to market practice and to rationalise the subsidies for the purchase of HDB flats. The revised mortgage financing package included measures such as credit assessment which would instil greater financial prudence and discipline among buyers of HDB flats.

    In May 1997, new measures were announced to manage the demand for new HDB flats. There are already 150,000 applicants on the HDB queue and the waiting time for new HDB flats is becoming too long. The new measures are necessary to re-prioritise the demand for new HDB flats so that HDB can cater to applicants who are in more urgent need of the HDB flats, especially first-timers who are waiting for the HDB flat to set up their homes.

Column: 236



    The recent announcements of changes addressed the two key issues in public housing policies. My Ministry would monitor the situation and would make adjustments to our policies where necessary.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee: Sir, the first question I want to ask the Minister is a clarification again. There has been some misconception among the public that the resale levy is also applicable to people who have purchased flats from the resale market. Is that correct or not?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, although we term it as a "resale levy", the resale levy is only applicable to those who want to buy a second flat from HDB. So the resale levy is not a capital gains tax. It is not a profit-sharing tax. It is not a levy on resale flat. The resale levy is only incurred if somebody has bought a first flat from HDB and wants to buy a second flat. So on the case that the Member has raised of somebody buying a resale flat, when he sells his flat it does not incur a resale levy.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee: Sir, I want to ask the Minister a second question. There is a very popular request that this resale levy be modified to base on a reducing time scale method. For example, if an applicant has stayed in the flat for five years, the resale levy can be 20%, but if he has stayed for 10 years, maybe it can be reduced to 10%, and if he has stayed for 15 years, it may be zero percent. Can that suggestion be considered?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, as I have explained, the resale levy is not a capital gains tax and therefore this idea of varying it depending on the term of the occupation of the flat does not apply. Those who buy a flat from the HDB for the first time enjoys a substantial subsidy. Those who buy a flat for the second time enjoy this same subsidy, which is not fair to all those who have not either enjoyed a subsidy or who have not enjoyed the second subsidy. So to make it more equitable, the second subsidy on the new HDB flat ought to be smaller than the first flat. Hence, the idea of a resale levy so that you will buy the flat from HDB and enjoy the first subsidy. The second time you buy a new flat, your subsidy ought to be smaller than the first subsidy.

Column: 237



     Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar): I want to ask the Minister why did HDB discontinue the premium scheme?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: The premium scheme represents a very big loophole for the lessees of big flats. For example, under the resale levy scheme, lessees of a 5-room flat has to pay a 20% levy. But they are allowed to pay, also as an option, a 10% premium on the next flat. So when they buy another 5-room flat, they will only pay a 10% premium of the second flat which will amount to a little over $20,000. This represents a very big loophole and, therefore, owners of big flats will all opt to pay for the premium and, in so doing, pay a very small premium for the second flat. The second subsidy they enjoy, therefore, is not very much smaller than the first subsidy enjoyed by first-timers. To make it more equitable and to rationalise the subsidies for all first-timers and upgraders, we have decided to remove the premium so that lessees of big flats will pay the requisite levy when they upgrade to another flat.

     Dr Vasoo: Will the Minister consider allowing those who have selected their flat but have not signed the lease agreement to opt for the premium scheme?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: HDB has clarified the operational details of the policies and indeed those who have selected their flat but are waiting for the keys to their flat up to this quarter will be allowed to come under the old scheme. This is made known in the press release and HDB will take out a full page advertisement in the Straits Times to explain to Singaporeans that this policy would not affect those who are already waiting for their flat or those who are selecting their flat for the second quarter of this year. So they will not come under the new policies. These new policies will not affect them.

PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS

Debate on the Address
(Third Allotted Day)


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [2nd June, 1997],

    `That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to:-

Column: 238



    "We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the Opening of the First Session of this Parliament.".' - [Dr Wang Kai Yuen].

    Question again proposed.
12.44 pm

     Mr Ong Kian Min (Pasir Ris): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to participate in this debate.

    Sir, I rise to speak in support of the motion moved by the hon. Member for Bukit Timah. The President, in his Address to Parliament, has emphasised the importance of strengthening our nation's competitiveness.

    I believe this is particularly important as we stand at the threshold of the 21st century. The new millennium will be an era of high technology and rapid development. To highlight just how rapidly technology is developing, we would recall that back in the mid-1960s there were only a few hundred transistors on the computer chip. Today, there are 7.5 million for the most powerful computer and that number is doubling every two years.

    With such exponential increase in processing power, the years ahead promise many exciting challenges. Singapore has risen to the challenge by keeping abreast of this rapid advancement. We are already making a headstart with programmes such as IT 2000 and Singapore One. Even for the young, $2 billion have been set aside in support of the IT programme for schools. We must continue to maintain this headstart using the best available technology for the continued progress of our nation.

    Although we have done well over the past 30 years, we must not be complacent and take prosperity for granted. We must not delude ourselves into thinking that the tried and tested system that has produced good results in the past will continue to produce good results for the future. There are many examples of this fallacious thinking. A number of East Asian tiger economies which enjoyed high growth in the recent past are already facing rough economic weather. Even Japan, which

Column: 239

remains by far the richest country in Asia, has suffered economically over the last few years. This has prompted its Prime Minister to call for drastic economic reform in his speech at the opening of the new parliamentary session early this year.

    Looking at specific industries in Singapore, one area that demands our close attention is our role as a regional hub. An example is telecommunications. At present, we enjoy the position of being a telecommunications hub with signals from the regional countries being routed through Singapore. However, the industry is developing very rapidly and there is no intrinsic reason which dictates the location of a hub in Singapore as exists in the location of a seaport or an airport. Other countries are putting in place huge capacities to carry signals. Telecommunications giants are setting up worldwide alliances, such as Global One. The technology of telecommunications is such that signals which are routed through Singapore can easily be re-routed through other locations that have the carry capacity and offer it at a more competitive price. To enhance Singapore's position as a telecommunications hub, we have to put in place an integrated package of sensitive and appropriate regulations, high quality and time-effective operations and maintenance personnel, as well as being price competitive to promote that Singapore is a total business centre.

    Closer to myself as a practising lawyer, similar trends are evident. Singapore is a hub for about 55 international law firms providing regional legal services. One issue which we should look into is how we can make Singapore law an "international commercial law" in the same way as English law and New York law function as international commercial law for international transactions. This requires that parties engaged in international transactions are confident that the commercial law is clear, predictable, modern, transparent and commercially relevant. All these qualities Singapore law shares with London and New York. This leads to the next question of how Singapore law firms can increase their role in this regional

Column: 240

legal hub. We need to assess and examine how Singapore lawyers can widen their regional capacity and role.

    With an ever-changing global environment, we must be prepared to put aside conventional wisdom in analysing emerging trends and developments and in working out solutions for Singapore. We must be nimble and ready to make swift changes and adjustments when the situation demands it.

    To quote from Tennessee Williams, the US playwright:

    `It is almost as if you were frantically constructing another world while the world you live in dissolves beneath your feet, and that your survival depends on completing this construction at least one second before the old habitation collapses.'

    Mr Speaker, Sir, it must never be said of us that the time for change was yesterday.

    Sir, I believe, if Singapore is to continue the economic miracle, it requires us to systematically identify our strategic advantages and weaknesses. We must build on our strengths and eradicate areas of weaknesses. I am confident that our fair and open meritocratic system is a sure foundation on which to consolidate the "Singapore Way" of organising ourselves and doing things.

    We can build a "Singapore Cluster" comparable to successful "clusters" in industries, such as the Silicon Valley in the area of technology, or the City of London in the area of finance, or Hollywood in the movie industry.

    As we advance into a highly technological 21st century, our concerns should include the building of a value system. This will unite our people and give us a firm base and a powerful platform to face the challenges of the future. Our togetherness and strong convictions will give us our cutting edge. A spirit of stalwart nationalism must accompany our strive for excellence.

    Recent unrest that occurred in as diverse places such as Xinjiang province in distant China and Kalimantan in Indonesia stems from economic disparity between various segments of the population. Therefore, even at a time of good

Column: 241

economic growth and prosperity enjoyed by a wide segment of our population, we must anticipate and address any disparity that may be building up between the successful and those who, relatively speaking, have not done as well.

    Sir, I would urge the more successful, who are the beneficiaries of this system, to lend a helping hand to those who are less successful and give them hope to break out of their circumstances. Every Singaporean in every segment of our society has a part to play in sharing, building, encouraging and bringing out the best in one another. It is not only the Government helping the less fortunate. It is not merely the most successful at the top of the ladder helping the one at the bottom. But it is every Singaporean at every level helping those around him and it goes on down the line in a caring and sharing chain, right down to the last person. This way we can make Singapore a home where people feel bonded to one another and the country. Such close-knit local communities with dense interlocking relationships will produce a resilient society that can hold its own against the winds of change.

    This spirit of mutual help and support should not be focused merely on people. Companies, businesses and all other organisations need help and support too. Singapore has only a population of 3 million. If we organise ourselves and work as individuals, we are only a nation of 3 million people. If we work smart, and work as a team, collectively we can be more than the individual parts put together.

    For a small country like Singapore, the public and private sectors can and should work closer together to forge a trusting and symbiotic relationship. Home-grown businesses need help and support to compete more effectively in the regional and global markets. The public sector and Government-linked corporations can help and support them to focus their energies on competing more effectively overseas. The civil service has started to change its traditional functions as mere regulators. The private sector businesses welcome this. I look forward to the public sector evolving to become facilitators of business and growth.

Column: 242



    Reciprocating, the private sector can contribute its ideas and expertise in planning for the needs of Singapore in the 21st century. It is heartening to note that at the macro level, the Government has formed the Committee on Singapore's Competitiveness to chart the strategic direction for the country's economic growth. Such brainstorming involving the public and private sectors can be extended to and will be particularly useful in the development of public facilities and the delivery of quality public services.

    To work as a team, we must learn to share, help each other, dwell deep into our internal strength as a united people so that collectively we can beat all external competition. We need to know our areas of strength and work in tandem with each other for the benefit of the whole. For such ties to form and work, we must believe that there is a much bigger world out there, and everyone can have more of the pie if we work together, instead of against each other.

    One negative attitude which runs against the grain of nation building and the building of the team spirit is kiasuism. The war-cry of kiasuism is - "grab as much as you can for yourself, forget about others!" In kiasuism the focus is on "I" and "me". But, survival of our nation has to do with the "we" and "us". Kiasuism concentrates on personal survival but, as a nation, we must focus on the survival of the nation. We are a people with a big heart, not a people who want to grab all we can at the expense of others. There is enough for everyone if you are willing to work in tandem.

    As individuals and Singaporeans, we must work as a nation and as a team. We must not merely look after our own interest, but the interest of our fellow citizens and nation. In place of kiasuism, let us make caring and sharing important values in our culture. As we move from the "I" orientation to the "we" orientation, we can ensure a legacy that will hold good for generations to come.

    We have come a long way since independence. Today, we have much more resources than in 1965. With this strong

Column: 243

base, we are in a much better position to compete in the increasingly competitive world markets and offer the generation to come a position of positive advantage to succeed in an even tougher millennium.

    On that note, Sir, I support the motion.

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon (Bukit Timah)( In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, we would like to thank the President for his Address on the Opening of this Parliament. I am confident that the people will give full support to the Government to make use of our favourable situation and opportunities now to realise the vision spelt out in Singapore 21.

    The President's Address has given us confidence for the future, but there are also some points for us to ponder over. For example, the President said that we are much stronger than what we were in 1965 and there is no reason for us to flinch from difficulties. But the problem is, at this time when Singaporeans have almost everything, do we still have the type of unity and high morale like our leaders in the early days who fought against the Japanese, strove for independence, faced the threat from communism, solved the myriad of problems resulting from the separation from Malaysia, racial riots, etc? So, are Singaporeans today able to rise to the occasion to protect and to defend our own country? This is not a question of "able" (yes) or "not able" (no), but a definite "able" (yes). If we want to be first class citizens, we want to be masters of Singapore, we have to make it a strong "yes".

    Our foreign reserves now stand at $107.7 billion, which ranks among the top ten in the world. We have a better economic structure and infrastructure; we have a better educational system, full employment and advanced national defence capability. But the question is: used to living in much better condition, are our younger generation able to face challenges with the same determination and undaunted fighting spirit of our first generation leaders?

    I am very happy to note that the Government is now promoting the

Column: 244

National Education programme. National Education must succeed. However, I hope that while promoting National Education, we must not forget the human factor, that is "EQ education". It is undeniable that we need to have good IT education and creative education so that we will be able to participate in the world-wide long-distance economic race and still remain in the leading position. Taking into consideration our present economic strength and our talent pool, there should be no problem. But the key issue is how to make National Education a success, and to ensure better cohesiveness among the people of Singapore in every generation. In this aspect, if we can pay more attention and place greater emphasis on "EQ education", we will be able to achieve double effect with half the effort.

    What is Emotional Quantum education? It involves our outlook of life, work attitude and integrity. In recent years, the Prime Minister has been promoting team spirit, integrity, moral values, the proper attitude of learning excellent social culture values, arts, and to build up a gracious society. These are actually the main factors of "EQ education". The scope of EQ education is very broad. It is the control centre of our thinking. It controls our conduct and our lifestyle. The quality of EQ education would affect the political and social practice of the country and the quality of our people.

    It involves the cultivation of our outlook of life, culture and arts, discipline, national character, courtesy, personality, ways of handling things, learning attitude, team spirit. For example, some soldiers are very highly patriotic and are prepared to sacrifice themselves for the nation, while some will betray the country for wealth; many people are disciplined and law-abiding, while some are prone to commit crimes; some people are serious in life, while others are happy-go-lucky; some people are prepared to sacrifice themselves for others while some are self-seeking. In addition, there are different emotions - happiness, anger, sadness, contentment, resentment, impatience, forgiveness, etc, which will affect the handling of marital and family relationships, public relations and communication with colleagues at work, boy-girl relationship, etc.

Column: 245



    Our Government is clean and honest, fair and unbiased, and our people are law-abiding, hardworking and always striving to improve themselves. The success in EQ education has much to do with these. But in some countries, governments are corrupt and society generally depraved. This stems from the failure in their EQ education. We have to correct the biasness in the EQ education. Our emotional education is successful, especially at a time when everybody is talking about information technology and computers. There is nothing wrong with learning to use a computer, because I am also learning how to use it. Now everybody has a computer at home. When a young man comes home, what is the first thing he does? Does he go straight to the computer or does he greet his parents or his family first? There should be a balance between technology and the human factor.

    According to a famous Japanese doctor, in his book `A Great Revolution in the Brain World', he mentioned that emotion had a great effect on our health and on our attitude towards life. His theory is that we should balance the usage of the right and left parts of our brains. When we talk about the emotion, it refers to the right brain which controls our potential for music and the arts, and our feelings and emotion. The author pointed out that most of the time, people put too much emphasis on the left brain which controls their rational operation, such as administering language, computation, science and technology, and computer information, etc, and neglected the positive and negative effects of the right brain on conducting social communications. If a person is full of confidence in life, the brain will produce a secretion known as the B-endorphin which will make him even more willing to contribute to society. On the contrary, if a person is under stress and pressure and he doesn't know how to handle them, the brain will secrete a toxin known as Noradrenalin which will not only affect his health but also make him do something which is anti-social. In other words, if we want stronger cohesion among Singaporeans, we have to complement National Education with a balance between the left brain (rational)

Column: 246

and the right brain (emotional) and place equal emphasis on material and spiritual advancement. How can we draw the people's attention to `emotional education'? We have to promote `emotional education' through the school, the family (parents and grandparents) and the work place (superiors and subordinates).

    (1) To foster teamwork and mutual help among students through the school.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I feel that the cultivation of EQ should start from the school. At a time when the Ministry of Education is placing a lot of emphasis on the `gifted programme' and on `teaching according to ability', we should not overlook the fact that streaming the children too early may make those in the Normal Stream, or even Express stream feel that they are born-losers or `second class'. The worst is even parents and teachers cannot bear such a stigma. It would have a very negative effect on the children. Since we have already set up a Committee on Singapore's Competitiveness to enhance our competitive edge, in order to inculcate in students and young citizens a sense of self-esteem and the willingness to contribute their best to their country, I hope the Ministry of Education will consider setting up a Committee of Specialised Education and invite educationalists, psychologists, scientists, sociologists and other experts who are specialised in the areas of education and children counselling to delve into the different stages of education for our students. Apart from encouraging students to exel in academic performance, the school can also group students into, say, teams of ten with similar learning ability to take part in after-school activities. This will not only improve individual performance, but also collective performance as a team. At the end of the year, some incentives, such as prizes for best team spirit based on their performance in their lessons, arts, sports, games, computer, etc. could be given. In addition, the schools can also reward the teams based on their attitude towards learning, scoial services, cooperation and leadership skills. The aim is to enable students of different talents to excel in

Column: 247

their respective fields, be it arts, science, technical, music or sports. In addition, they will be able to work together as a group with the best team spirit. In this way, every child's talent will be put to optimum use to achieve the goal of the team as a whole.
